Thomas Jefferson (April 13, 1743 – July 4, 1826) was an American Founding Father, the principal author of the Declaration of Independence, and the third President of the United States (1801–1809). Born into a prominent Virginia family, he was educated at the College of William & Mary and later traveled to Europe, where he studied architecture, science, and political philosophy.

Jefferson married Martha Wayles Skelton in 1772. The couple had six children together, but only two survived to adulthood. After Martha's death in 1782, Jefferson became the largest landowner in Virginia. He was actively involved in politics during the American Revolution, serving as a delegate to the Second Continental Congress.

In 1776, Jefferson drafted the Declaration of Independence, which proclaimed the thirteen American colonies' intention to separate from Britain. This document became a powerful symbol of liberty and equality worldwide. After the Revolutionary War, Jefferson held various public offices, including the first United States Secretary of State under President George Washington and later as Vice President under President John Adams.

Jefferson's greatest accomplishment as president was the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, which doubled the size of the United States. He established the Lewis and Clark Expedition to explore the newly acquired territory and to learn about its geography, resources, and native inhabitants.

Despite his many accomplishments, Jefferson faced criticism, particularly for his relationship with Sally Hemings, a mixed-race slave who lived at Monticello, his Virginia plantation. It is now widely believed that Jefferson fathered several of Hemings's children. This has been a source of controversy and debate among historians.

In his retirement, Jefferson devoted himself to his plantation and his beloved Monticello, where he worked tirelessly to perfect its design and construction. He also authored several books, including "Notes on the State of Virginia," in which he addressed the social, political, and economic issues of his time.

Jefferson was born in Shadwell, Virginia, to a moderately prosperous family. He had a thirst for knowledge, leading him to study under illiterate tutors before becoming a student at the College of William & Mary. During his time there, he honed his ideas of liberty and self-government, which would later inform his political philosophy.


After completing his studies, Jefferson began practicing law in 1767 and soon became involved in politics. His interests in enlightenment ideals, agrarianism, and states' rights defined his political career. In 1775, during the American Revolution, Jefferson was appointed to the Virginia legislature, where he promoted separation from British rule.


His political rise continued, and in 1776, he was chosen to draft the Declaration of Independence. This document would become a symbol of freedom and human rights. Following the Revolution, Jefferson served as the Governor of Virginia and later as the United States Minister to France, where his diplomatic skills gained recognition.


In 1790, President George Washington appointed Jefferson as his first Vice President, and after Washington's presidency, Jefferson became the third President of the United States, serving from 1801 to 1809. His presidency is noted for the Louisiana Purchase, which nearly doubled the size of the nation, and the Lewis and Clark expedition, which explored the western territories.


Beyond politics, Jefferson was a scholar, inventor, and architect. He founded the University of Virginia, designed Monticello, his personal estate, and made significant contributions to the field of linguistics, particularly with his work on the language of the Native American peoples.


Jefferson died on July 4, 1826, the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. Today, he remains an iconic figure in American history, remembered for his contributions to the principles and expansion of the United States.

Thomas Jefferson, the principal author of the Declaration of Independence and the third President of the United States, was born on April 13, 1743, in Shadwell, Virginia.

Jefferson, a polymath, and a renowned architect, was deeply influenced by the Enlightenment ideas and believed in the power of knowledge and education. He was a man of wide interests and many accomplishments, including being a member of the first United States Senate, Secretary of State under President George Washington, Vice President under John Adams, and President from 1801 to 1809.

One of Jefferson's most notable achievements was his vision and execution of the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, which doubled the size of the United States. He also commissioned the Lewis and Clark expedition to explore the newly acquired western territories. 

As an advocate for religious freedom, Jefferson played a crucial role in the establishment of the University of Virginia, which was designed to serve as a center for learning and enlightenment. His design for the university campus, as well as his many personal accomplishments in architecture, earned him the title "Father of the University of Virginia."

Jefferson owned slaves throughout his life, and was also a prominent slave owner and breeder. Despite his advocacy for individual freedom, his personal life was marred by his slaveholding practices. However, he consistently advocated for the gradual emancipation of slaves and the eventual abolition of slavery.

In his later years, Jefferson continued to write extensively, including his famous "Notes on the State of Virginia," which offered a sweeping survey of American politics, economics, and society, as well as a defense of his views on slavery and Native Americans. Jefferson died on July 4, 1826, just hours after his close friend and fellow Founding Father, John Adams.

Thomas Jefferson remains a key figure in American history, remembered for his significant contributions to the country's growth, development, and constitutional foundations. His legacy as an author, politician, architect, and champion of education continues to inspire future generations.

Jefferson was born into a family of planters, and his early education was overseen by tutors. He later studied law at the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia, and was admitted to the bar in 1767. He also acquired a vast library of books, which would later influence his thinking and writings.


Political Career

In 1775, Jefferson became a delegate to the Virginia legislature, where he championed colonial rights. As tensions with Great Britain escalated, Jefferson served as a member of the Virginia Committee of Correspondence and was elected to the Continental Congress, where he was an outspoken advocate for independence.


As a diplomat in Paris, Jefferson gained European insight, which he later applied to his tenure as the United States Minister to France. He drafted the Declaration of Independence, a document that not only announced the colonies' intent to break free from British rule but also outlined fundamental principles of human rights that would influence future generations.


Presidency

Jefferson was elected President in 1800 on a platform of limited government and agrarian democracy. His presidency saw the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, which doubled the size of the nation. His advocacy for the exploration of the Western territories led to the Lewis and Clark Expedition.


Later Life

After his presidency, Jefferson returned to his beloved Monticello, where he continued his scholarly pursuits. He also engaged in political battles, supporting the embargo against Britain and France and opposing the formation of political parties.


Jefferson's life was a tapestry of intellectual pursuits and public service. His ideas about government, democracy, and individual rights continue to resonate today.

Today we honor the life and legacy of Thomas Jefferson, the third President of the United States and a leading figure in American history. Born on April 13, 1743, in Shadwell, Virginia, Jefferson was raised in a family of modest means but rich intellectual curiosity. His father, Peter Jefferson, was a planter and surveyor, while his mother, Jane Randolph Jefferson, came from one of Virginia's most distinguished families.

Jefferson attended the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, where he was greatly influenced by the Enlightenment thinkers such as John Locke and Voltaire. Here, he studied law under George Wythe and became a respected lawyer in Virginia. His legal career flourished, as he successfully defended his friend and fellow founding father, Aaron Burr, in Burr's treason trial.

As a Virginia statesman, Jefferson rose to prominence as a leader of the revolutionary movement against British rule. In 1776, he authored the Declaration of Independence, which articulated the principles of human rights and government's responsibility to its citizens. As a member of the Continental Congress, Jefferson served on the committee responsible for drafting the document, sharing credit with fellow founding fathers such as Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, and Roger Sherman.

Following the success of the American Revolution, Jefferson sought to expand and diversify the nation's economy and territory. In 1784, he became the American Minister to France, where he cultivated a friendship with the revolutionary leader, Marquis de Lafayette. Later, as Secretary of State under President George Washington, Jefferson helped negotiate the 1794 Treaty of Peace and Amity with Tripoli, ending the Barbary Wars.

Jefferson was elected as the Vice President of the United States in 1796 and assumed the Presidency in 1801 after his election to the office. As President, Jefferson championed the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, acquiring over 800,000 square miles of land west of the Mississippi River, effectively doubling the size of the United States. He was also a strong advocate for religious freedom and educational reform, supporting the founding of the University of Virginia in 1819.

text:
Birth and Early Life

Thomas Jefferson, born on April 13, 1743, in Shadwell, Virginia, was the third child of Peter Jefferson and Jane Randolph. He was raised in a well-to-do plantation-owning family, where his parents instilled in him the values of self-reliance, education, and independence. Jefferson's father, an accomplished surveyor and farmer, played a significant role in his life. His mother, who came from one of Virginia's most prominent families, also heavily influenced his upbringing and future endeavors.

Education

At the age of 13, Jefferson was sent to the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia, where he received a broad education that combined the classics with mathematics, metaphysics, and modern languages. At college, he was greatly influenced by the ideas of the Enlightenment, including those of John Locke, whose thoughts on government and natural rights shaped Jefferson's future worldview.

Legal and Political Career

In 1767, Jefferson moved to Williamsburg and began practicing law. He quickly established a reputation for his skill and intellect, as well as his devotion to the colonies' cause. During the American Revolution, Jefferson was a delegate to the Virginia House of Burgesses, where he voiced strong support for independence.

In 1776, as a member of the Virginia legislature, Jefferson drafted the original version of the Declaration of Independence. Although he had reservations about the use of enslaved labor and women's rights, the Declaration of Independence became the cornerstone of the United States' vision of liberty and justice.

Tenure as U.S. Secretary of State

In 1775, Jefferson joined the Continental Congress as a delegate representing Virginia. His eloquent advocacy for independence led to his role as the primary author of the Declaration of Independence. This document, which articulated the principles of the new nation, is considered a cornerstone of American democracy.

After the American Revolution, Jefferson held various government positions, including Secretary of State and Vice President under President John Adams. As the third President, Jefferson continued his expansionist agenda, which led to the Louisiana Purchase, a massive territory doubling the size of the United States.

Jefferson's administration focused on supporting economic growth and westward expansion while championing republicanism and limited government. However, his presidency was marred by the Embargo Act of 1807, which harmed American merchants and caused political unrest.

In addition to his political career, Jefferson had an interest in scientific and educational pursuits. He established the University of Virginia in 1819 and served as its president until his death in 1826. Jefferson is also well-known for his work on the Lewis and Clark expedition, which expanded American knowledge of the western territories.

Jefferson married Martha Wayles Skelton in 1772, and they had six children. Tragically, only two of their children survived into adulthood. After Martha's death in 1782, Jefferson never remarried.

Jefferson had a keen interest in science, philosophy, and European architecture, and during his studies, he met influential figures, including George Wythe and George Mason.

He became a lawyer in 1767, and throughout the American Revolutionary period, Jefferson served in several political roles. He was a member of the Virginia House of Burgesses (1769-1775), a delegate to the First and Second Continental Congresses (1774-1779), and the Governor of Virginia (1779-1781).

Jefferson drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776, wherein he argued for the inalienable rights of "Life, Liberty, and the pursuit of Happiness." In the early years of the United States, Jefferson served as the first Secretary of State under President George Washington (1789-1793) and later as Vice President (1797-1801).

In 1801, Jefferson became the third president of the United States, serving two terms. During his administration, he oversaw the Louisiana Purchase (1803), which doubled the size of the country, and he advocated for the Lewis and Clark expedition. Jefferson also introduced policies like the Embargo Act (1807) and the Non-Intercourse Act (1809), as a response to growing tensions with Britain and France.

In his later years, Jefferson focused on education and founded the University of Virginia (1819). He remained active in public affairs, campaigning for James Madison's re-election, and continued his diplomatic mission in France until 1809.

After the American Revolution, Jefferson continued his political career, serving as the United States Minister to France and the Vice President under President John Adams. In 1801, Jefferson was elected President, leading the country through the Louisiana Purchase, which doubled the size of the nation, and promoting the Embargo Act to protect American interests. Thomas Jefferson was not only a statesman but also a learned man, well-versed in literature, science, and architecture. He founded the University of Virginia in 1819, and its design and planning are still admired today.
